body: I'm not positive if the read-only directory eventually got cleaned up some how; I can't find the JUnit temp directory in my user's temp directory. Nevertheless we don't want it to throw an exception in any case.
Can you please provide the implementation of `setAttribute(directory, ATTRIBUTE_DOS_READONLY, true);`?

It's part of the Java NIO API: [`Files.setAttribute(â€¦)`](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/nio/file/Files.html#setAttribute(java.nio.file.Path,java.lang.String,java.lang.Object,java.nio.file.LinkOption...))

In this case `ATTRIBUTE_DOS_READONLY` is a constant that equates to `dos:readonly`. You can find the values in [`DosFileAttributeView`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/attribute/DosFileAttributeView.html). See also [`DosFileAttributeView.name()`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/attribute/DosFileAttributeView.html#name--).
I agree that this was an oversight. @garretwilson Could you please submit a PR to fix that?

> Could you please submit a PR to fix that?

In theory I would love to, but I'm several layers deep in bug reports, PRs, etc. For the moment I'm just removing the `read-only` flag in my unit test. Otherwise I'll never get to the end of my current ticket, much less my current project.

I just wanted to file the ticket so it would at least be known so that it could be addressed some day. I don't think it has super-high severity or priority. If things calm down I would be glad to address it.

Another note: I don't know if you already have code to do this, but it's not strightforwardâ€”it requires detecting Java NIO support for DOS file attributes and POSIX file attributes, the latter of which sets read-only status by manipulating the _parent directory_ permissions, etc. I'm working on this myself in my own library in [`JAVA-312`](https://globalmentor.atlassian.net/browse/JAVA-312). I have to reopen the ticket and implement the POSIX version. I was just now figuring out how to test this on Linux using a Docker image. Lots of fun still ahead.

> Another note: I don't know if you already have code to do this, but it's not strightforwardâ€”it requires detecting Java NIO support for DOS file attributes and POSIX file attributes, ...

```java
Set<String> supportedFileAttributeViews = tempDir.getFileSystem().supportedFileAttributeViews();
// dos is supported on unix
supportedFileAttributeViews.contains("dos") && !supportedFileAttributeViews.contains("unix")
```

Am I missing something?

```java
readAttributes(tempDir, BasicFileAttributes.class) instanceof DosFileAttributes
```

I would not recommend this. This looks like relying on an implementation detail that can change at any point.

```java
setAttribute(directory, ATTRIBUTE_DOS_READONLY, false);
```

I find this hard to read. I would do the following

```java
Files.getFileAttributeView(directory, DosFileAttributeView.class).setReadOnly(false);
```

> Am I missing something?

One thing you're missing is the rest of the sentence which you replaced with ellipsis ðŸ˜‰ regarding the different levels of "read-only" designation in POSIX for directories. My entire sentence taken into context was making the point that there were several gotchas involved, each one in itself perhaps not being too onerous, but taken together meant that the task is not straightforward as a whole.


~~> `supportedFileAttributeViews.contains("dos")`~~

~~Doing a "contains" without a proper parsing of the string is not best practices, and has launched a thousand bugs, as the decades of parsing `User-Agent` strings for browser detection [will bear out](https://webaim.org/blog/user-agent-string-history/). You might think that's being nit-picky, but it adds to the multitude of gotchas making this not straightforward.~~ (_Edit:_ Ignore this paragraphâ€”I was mistakenly thinking a single string was being checked to contain `"dos"`, but actually it's a `Set<String>`, which makes this logic correct. I was glancing over this too quickly, having historically seen too many people detecting substrings in an incorrect way. This was a side-note anywayâ€”the larger point is that there's a few things to watch out for regarding read-only-ness across platforms.)

I didn't say it's hard. I'm just saying it's not something I can dash off in a couple of lines in five minutes.

> Doing a "contains" without a proper parsing of the string is not best practices, and has launched a thousand bugs, as the decades of parsing `User-Agent` strings for browser detection [will bear out](https://webaim.org/blog/user-agent-string-history/). You might think that's being nit-picky, but it adds to the multitude of gotchas making this not straightforward.

Please tell me what the proper parsing here would look like and the possible gotchas.

> Please tell me what the proper parsing here would look like and the possible gotchas.

Actually I made a mistake hurriedly looking over your code; I thought that `contains(â€¦)` was being used on an individual string value (e.g. `"some string containing dos and other things.contains("dos")`). In this case the value is in fact a `Set<String>`, and `"dos"` is indeed the full name of an implementation of `DosFileAttributeView`, which means that logic is correct for detecting if a `DosFileAttributeView` is used. I'll edit my answer above to reflect this.

> Actually I made a mistake hurriedly looking over your code; I thought that `contains(â€¦)` was being used on an individual string value (e.g. `"some string containing dos and other things.contains("dos")`). In this case the value is in fact a `Set<String>`, and `"dos"` is indeed the full name of an implementation of `DosFileAttributeView`, which means that logic is correct for detecting if a `DosFileAttributeView` is used. I'll edit my answer above to reflect this.

Thanks for clarifying, I though I missed something or overlooked something. All good.

issue.title: Set readonly attribute to false if `DosFileAttributeView` is supported

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Fixes https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/3352.

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org.junit.platform.commons/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)

issue.title: Clean up performance build directory on Windows
issue.body: This is a workaround of https://github.com/gradle/gradle-private/issues/3961 Because some read-only files are created in `performance/build/santaTrackerAndroidBuild`, we have to clean them up at the end of performance tests, otherwise it breaks the subsequent builds.
